reviewText:
'Oh this game looks so easy, I could do that...'

I will now proceed to give a review of the UK's own Broadmoor high-security psychiatric hospital.

Firstly, all the staff there take good care of those of us who have been admitted. We get to do regular daily activities, we have 3 meals a day (All cooked on site, full courses) and we do get to spend time with other patients should we be having a good day. My room itself is fairly plain; 4 walls, 1 window, a bed, a sink with 2 taps; and recently I've even been allowed a few photos on my wall and a carpet!

A normal day consists of going to the mess hall for breakfast at 8am sharp. Well that's the case for my group, anyway, as not everyone is allowed to eat at the exact same time. The doctors say it's because it could be unsafe having that many patients in a room together. After breakfast we have classes for certain activities. My favourite is art because it allows me to express both my personalities, and expel my rage without causing damage to another human. I like to draw pictures with orange squares, black squares and blue triangles, because I see them in my dreams. My group has lunch at 1.30pm. After we have lunch we are taken to the medical wing where we undergo evaluation physically and mentally to assess our progress. Sometimes, depending on how we've done, we have to go for more rigorous tests, otherwise we just move onto the next part of our day. After our evaluations we're allowed to go out into the yard in small groups to have some fresh air. We can play sports with the assigned trainer for that day, or just relax in the sun. When we've finished in the yard it's time for dinner, at 6pm. We tend to have dinner in bigger groups because there are more staff to help out at that time. Anyway, after dinner we do group reading, in which we have to talk about the books. My group leader says it's to help with communication with others. It's nice, I really like it. Finally, at 8 o'clock pm, we're allowed to pick a book and take it back to our room so we can read if we wish to at night. It helps a lot of the patients keep calm when the lights go out.

Treatment here is really nice, although sometimes if we start to show increasing signs of instability or anger, the doctors and nurses can and will use a straight jacket or sedation depending on the situation at hand. I haven't had this happen to me a lot, only when I have the bad dreams of the orange and black squares and the blue triangles.

Occasionally my family come to visit, to see how I am. I like seeing my family, although I miss my brother. My last memory of him was sitting at my computer playing a video game, I think it had the word 'Impossible' in the title, but I can't really remember. It's all blurry. My family normally come once a month and sometimes they just seem upset to see me, but my personal nurse assures me that it's just me worrying too much.

I really like it here, although I can't remember much from the real world anymore. My nurse says that I will have to stay here for possibly another decade, but I'm okay with that because everything in here seems normal to me now. All I can really remember from my old life is playing video games, but ever since I got admitted I suddenly didn't miss playing them. I'm not sure if there's a connection there. I don't think so.

Overall that is my life in a nut-shell now. It's not a glamorous life, but it's quaint and quiet and it's my life, what it is and what it is going to be for the next decade or so.

Rating: 6 / 10

I don't have the patience and time to finish this, so I took the easy route by placing checkpoint flags that let you start from your specific point in the run. Even then it takes some time to finish a level.

All in all it is a nice game to have fun with for a while, until you had enough and go for some easy achievements. Or go for gold. Recommended because you won't forget it soon.

The Impossible Game is a game developed by FlukeDude, an Indie game developer who started off making Mobile Phone apps (If this game wasn't obvious enough already).

The Impossible Game is on several different platforms with it coming to the PC last, so if you're more interested in getting it for a Console then here's what it's on:

The idea of The Impossible Game is simple, jump over the obsticles to make it to the end of the level & show off to your friends, so how do i go about reviewing such a simple game?

Well here's how i see it, The Impossible Game is very simple in design & anybody can pick it up & know exactly what to do after about 20 seconds of play, however there are a few things that make this game challenging & often lead to fits of OMG AS IF!" or "OH BULL â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥"

reviewText:
This game should be renamed to Stockholm Syndrome. It constantly treats you like crap and laughs in your face as you fail over and over again. But for some reason, something deep inside you makes you keep playing this simple, bare-bones platformer over and over again.

Here's a video of the game if you want to see just how impossible this is. If you would rather read, then just continue below.

http://youtu.be/iaEb4gAWnxY

So what is this game about? You play as a hot-blooded cube determined to propel itself forever to the right, and it will stop at nothing until it reaches the end. Spikes, walls, and pratfalls are you're only enemies. But they are a mighty force to be reckoned with. Timing is the key factor to avoid instant death, and the only thing your hard-boiled cube can do is jump. But damn is that jumping satisfying. Everything relies on your split-second reflexes, and when you do make it, it feels good. Real good.

But let's talk about more of the game's features. On the top of the screen is a counter that will surely go up for ever time you die. But don't fret, your cube is swiftly reborn, better, stronger, and wiser than the last. Well, just as long as you don't make stupid mistakes. And everytime you retry, you will slowly inch your way closer to the end goal of beating the impossible game.

There is a total of 5 levels you can play, each one with challenging mechanics like flipping the screen or falling blocks. There is also a level editor you can use to make more impossible levels if you ever do the unthinkable and beat the game. But for simple cubes like myself, there is a system of putting down flags that restart you from where you set them down, which allows steady progression towards the end instead of having to begin all over again. Sure it might be called practice" or "weenie" mode

reviewText:
The Impossible Game is a short but challenging platforming-type game where you control a cube trying to make it through the end of an obstacle course full of pits, spikes, and non-existant gravity.

This is a very fun game, and that's primarily because of it's difficulty and great soundtrack. All you can do is jump. The only thing to aid you is the sound of the music as the soundtrack mostly goes with the course. You'll die again and again, but you'll keep coming back for more because you want to beat that stage, and hear the entire song. You get an amazing feeling of satisfaction when you accomplish it, let me tell you. It's a test of your memory and reflexes. Play to win.

The game's length can depend on how good you are, but the level selection is rather short. It's only 5 levels long, and the length of each stage is around 2 minutes. The replay value comes to just simply beating the level. The only other thing you can do is create levels of your own in the level editor. If you like that kind of thing, then by all means, go for it.

Overall, The Impossible Game is an addicting, very hard game with a very upbeat soundtrack. If you love challenge and reflex games, then buy this. If that's not your cup of tea, you might not find much enjoyment out of it.

7/10

reviewText:
One button puzzle platforming game.

Chances are you already know whether you like these or not, but the lack of checkpoints and the lack of vision hamper this game.

This game becomes boring though, as the beginning of each track just becomes this long dull slog that you can complete flawlessly, even with your eyes shut, but which you must travel through to get to the bits you are yet to memorise and thus die in. Unless you want to start spawning flags to bypass this (by entering practise mode), and practise each section by itself, whilst losing the cool music in the process, then you must endure this slog each and every death.

I mean, games like Super Hexagon have similar issues, but this is a puzzle platformer. So the level -never changes-. An easy game with randomly generated terrain at least keeps the player awake, but a long puzzle platformer frustrates the beginner, only to bore the intermediate before only finally pleasing the master (who has to make the starting journey once or twice).

The music is pretty good though, but the practise mode music is rubbish. Also changing the rhythm on the player by changing the track between practise and 'real' mode is unhelpful at the least.

The game is also slightly glitchy (the player doesn't start on the ground after death, and at one point my character just vanished from the field).

Really, these games can be enjoyable for a time, but I wouldn't pay money for them (or, at least, again). Find a flash variant of the same thing on Newgrounds or some other Flash game user-submitted portal.
And this one isn't particularly 'impossible' or special or even mechanically or graphically better than these Flash games, just long with a limited field of view to force your death many times, until you finally memorise everything.

I might pay money for the music though, if it were in standalone form.

Addictive, light, engaging, and frustrating.

This isn't a game you should sit down and play for hours at a time. If you get the 500 attempts achievement, you're crazy. Or hunting for achievements. Either way.

This is a game you pick up when you need to clear your brain for five minutes. The game DEMANDS your full attention and is great at clearing the cobwebs and refocusing yourself between tasks. The repetitive nature of the game makes it relatively easy to learn a level over time and see steady but slow improvement in your good runs, which means you'll keep coming back for more. By the time you beat all the levels, you'll have gotten your money's worth and then some.

On the other hand, if you adopt the idea that you MUST beat the game and get obsessed, you'll find that the long term learning curve pales to the short term frustration-induced failure rate. Be prepared to hate and hate hard.

Simple, yet incredibly addicting and challenging. After beating level 1 the first time, I felt a sense of accomplishment. Every time I died, it was because something I did wrong and needed to remember for the next run through. You will die a lot, but you don't have to wait because you will almost immediately start over again (no load times). If you enjoy simple puzzle games, this is for you. Also, there's a level editor to create your own levels and share with others.
